dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A listener writes in, 'Warren's stance on Big Tech is a rare point of clarity in a field of timid candidates.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A listener writes in, 'Warren's stance on Big Tech is a rare point of clarity in a field of timid candidates.'

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's interesting that the text mentions Ted Cruz specifically as taking what it calls 'unprincipled stands' on tech regulation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's interesting that the text mentions Ted Cruz specifically as taking what it calls 'unprincipled stands' on tech regulation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Other candidates, most notably Senator Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota, have also taken principled stands.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and there's this idea that, um, the debate around tech now is being compared to financial deregulation in the late 1980s.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and there's this idea that, um, the debate around tech now is being compared to financial deregulation in the late 1980s.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The debate about how to regulate the sector is eerily reminiscent of the debate over financial regulation in the early 2000s.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is a pretty striking parallel, honestly. It feels like we're seeing some of the same arguments play out all over again.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is a pretty striking parallel, honestly. It feels like we're seeing some of the same arguments play out all over again.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And the piece points out that, uh, back then, the financial industry was paying salaries so low that talented regulators just couldn't be retained.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the piece points out that, uh, back then, the financial industry was paying salaries so low that talented regulators just couldn't be retained.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And the financial industry put its money where its mouth was, paying salaries so much higher than those in the public sector that any research assistant the Federal Reserve System trained to work on financial issues would be enticed with offers exceeding what their bosss boss was earning.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly—so if we don't learn from that, we might see the same staffing problems in tech antitrust divisions today.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly-so if we don't learn from that, we might see the same staffing problems in tech antitrust divisions today.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There will be similar problems staffing tech regulatory offices and antitrust legal divisions if the push for tighter regulation gains traction.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But one key difference they note is that, unlike finance, Big Tech might be less vulnerable to causing a global economic meltdown.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But one key difference they note is that, unlike finance, Big Tech might be less vulnerable to causing a global economic meltdown.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And the US and world economy are, if anything, even more vulnerable to Big Tech than to the financial sector, owing both to cyber aggression and vulnerabilities in social media that can pervert political debate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Though they do mention that US-based cyber instability could still have worldwide effects, which is pretty concerning.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Though they do mention that U S-based cyber instability could still have worldwide effects, which is pretty concerning.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A US-based cyber crisis could easily do the same.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's this reference to Larry Lindsey's report in the UK, which the author calls 'very useless'—pretty harsh criticism.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's this reference to Larry Lindsey's report in the U K, which the author calls 'very useless'-pretty harsh criticism.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Recently, the United Kingdom commissioned an expert group, chaired by former President Barack Obamas chief economist (and now my colleague) Jason Furman, that produced a very useful report on approaches to the tech sector.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it really underscores how fragmented and ineffective some of these regulatory efforts have been so far.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it really underscores how fragmented and ineffective some of these regulatory efforts have been so far.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The article also brings up China, pointing out that US tech monopolies haven't dominated there because local regulators acted faster.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The article also brings up China, pointing out that U S tech monopolies haven't dominated there because local regulators acted faster.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And, perhaps outside of China, it is a global problem, because US tech monopolies have often achieved market dominance before local regulators and politicians know what has happened.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is a contrast to how things have played out in the US and Europe, where regulation has been slower to catch up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is a contrast to how things have played out in the U S and Europe, where regulation has been slower to catch up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And, perhaps outside of China, it is a global problem, because US tech monopolies have often achieved market dominance before local regulators and politicians know what has happened. The European Union, in particular, has been trying to steer its own course on technology regulation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's that quote from The Atlantic, warning about economic decline and the risk of plutocracy—pretty heavy stuff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's that quote from The Atlantic, warning about economic decline and the risk of plutocracy-pretty heavy stuff.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It may indicate whether the American democracy, like all the democratic experiments which have preceded it, is to become extinct because the people had not wit enough or virtue enough to make the common good supreme.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It really frames this as a much bigger issue than just market competition; it's about the future of democracy and fairness.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really frames this as a much bigger issue than just market competition; it's about the future of democracy and fairness.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So ultimately, the debate Warren is pushing isn't about socialism; it's about making capitalist competition stronger and fairer.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So ultimately, the debate Warren is pushing isn't about socialism; it's about making capitalist competition stronger and fairer.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The debate that Warren has joined is not about whether to establish socialism. It is about making capitalist competition fairer and, ultimately, stronger.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is a message that, uh, seems to be getting drowned out by lobbying and superficial analysis right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is a message that, uh, seems to be getting drowned out by lobbying and superficial analysis right now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: An open, informed discussion that is not squelched by lobbying dollars is a national imperative.

artist_script:
HostA: A listener writes in, 'Warren's stance on Big Tech is a rare point of clarity in a field of timid candidates.'
HostB: Yeah, and it's interesting that the text mentions Ted Cruz specifically as taking what it calls 'unprincipled stands' on tech regulation.
HostA: Right, and there's this idea that, um, the debate around tech now is being compared to financial deregulation in the late 1980s.
HostB: Which is a pretty striking parallel, honestly. It feels like we're seeing some of the same arguments play out all over again.
HostA: And the piece points out that, uh, back then, the financial industry was paying salaries so low that talented regulators just couldn't be retained.
HostB: Exactly—so if we don't learn from that, we might see the same staffing problems in tech antitrust divisions today.
HostA: But one key difference they note is that, unlike finance, Big Tech might be less vulnerable to causing a global economic meltdown.
HostB: Though they do mention that US-based cyber instability could still have worldwide effects, which is pretty concerning.
HostA: And then there's this reference to Larry Lindsey's report in the UK, which the author calls 'very useless'—pretty harsh criticism.
HostB: Yeah, it really underscores how fragmented and ineffective some of these regulatory efforts have been so far.
HostA: The article also brings up China, pointing out that US tech monopolies haven't dominated there because local regulators acted faster.
HostB: Which is a contrast to how things have played out in the US and Europe, where regulation has been slower to catch up.
HostA: And then there's that quote from The Atlantic, warning about economic decline and the risk of plutocracy—pretty heavy stuff.
HostB: It really frames this as a much bigger issue than just market competition; it's about the future of democracy and fairness.
HostA: So ultimately, the debate Warren is pushing isn't about socialism; it's about making capitalist competition stronger and fairer.
HostB: Which is a message that, uh, seems to be getting drowned out by lobbying and superficial analysis right now.
